member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Differencing.IHierarchicalStringDifferenceService
member.summary: This service has several shortcut methods that compute differences over strings, snapshots, and spans. Differences are computed according to the specified , starting with the most general type (line is more general than word, and word is more general than character).
member.example:
Given string A: --- This is a line! --- And string B: --- This is but a line! ---
The returned difference collection contains one line difference, which maps to line 1 of each string. This difference contains one word difference, which is the addition of the words "but" and " ".

remarks.para: This type is deprecated. Use instead, which allows you to retrieve an for a specific content type and provides a superset of the methods available on this interface.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Differencing.Difference
member.summary: Represents a single difference in the set of differences of two lists of elements.
member.remarks: Each difference consists of a left span and a right span, either of which may have zero length (that is, the operation may be an add operation or a delete operation). The text before and after the difference matches. In general, differencess are non-null. However, when the difference appears at the beginning of the lists of differences, the "before" is null, and when the difference appears at the end of the lists, the "after" is null.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Differencing.ITextDifferencingService
member.summary: This service has methods that compute differences over strings, snapshots, and spans. Differences are computed according to the specified , starting with the most general type (line is more general than word, and word is more general than character). This service is meant to be provided by extenders to override the diff behavior by content type, thus allowing more control over the differences produced and how they align semantically (based upon the given language/content type).

remarks.para:
This is a MEF component part, and should be exported with the following attribute:
[Export(typeof(ITextDifferencingService))]
Component exporters must add at least one content type attribute to specify the content types for which the component is valid, such as:
[ContentType("basic")]
Use the to get the most specific for a particular content type.

Implementors of this class are free to interpret differencing fairly liberally. For example, a text differencing service for C# files could perform differencing by namespace/class/method, and then return these results in line form (or whatever is requested by the ). To that end, the results returned are also allowed to be non-minimal, allowing implementations to return results that fit better into the semantic model of a given language (in order to try to more closely match user intent, instead of being technically minimal). The normal contract of does still apply, however, in that differences cannot overlap, are sorted, etc.

When calling into an instance of this interface and choosing a , you should be using , unless a different word splitting behavior is explicitly needed. This allows the individual implementation latitude to apply the best word splitting rules for the given content type.

member.summary: Computes the differences between two snapshot spans, using the given difference options.
member.param: The left span. In most cases this is from an "old" snapshot.
The right span. In most cases this is from a "new" snapshot.
The options to use.

A callback for retrieving the text of snapshot lines (when performing differencing at the line level) that can optionally filter/modify the text, as long as it doesn't introduce line breaks (i.e. split the given line into multiple lines).
member.returns: A hierarchical collection of differences.

remarks.para: The can be used for things like ignoring all intraline whitespace or case during line differencing.

Also, the is only used for line-level differencing. If word/character differencing is requested, the implementation should use the original snapshot text directly, as there is no guaranteed way to map from words in a filtered line back to the original line.

The will be called only for full lines that intersect each requested . If a line only partially intersects the given left or right span, then the intersection of the line and the span is used directly.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Differencing.StringDifferenceOptions.Locality
member.summary: The greatest distance a differencing element (line, span, or character) can move and still be considered part of the same source. A value of 0 disables locality checking.

remarks.para: The use of locality in the default differencing implementation is now deprecated, and the value of this field is ignored (the same as being 0).

For example, if Locality is set to 100, a line is considered the same line if it is separated by 100 or fewer lines from its neighboring lines. If it is separated by more than 100 lines, it is considered a different line.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IPersistentSpan
member.summary: Describes span in a document that remains valid even when the document is closed, opened or modified (while it is open).

remarks.para: PersistentSpans are similar to s, except they can be created on closed documents and will continue to track even when a document is closed and reopened.
These spans only track changes made while the document is open. They will not track changes made to the document while the document is closed (through Notepad or something similar).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IPersistentSpan.TryGetStartLineIndex(System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Get the starting point of the span as a line number and offset from the start of the line.
member.param: Line number of the start point.
Character offset from the start of the line containing the start point.
member.returns: true if the the out parameters are valid; false otherwise (in which case TryGetSpan will work).

remarks.para: This method can be used on any span if the underlying document is open.

If the underlying document is closed, then this method can be used if either the document was created on the closed document using the line/index method of the factory or the document had ever been opened after the span was created.
In general, you should try this method (and ) before using .

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IReadOnlyRegion
member.summary: A handle that tracks a possibly empty read-only region of text.

remarks.para: The text in a read-only region is not necessarily immutable; a read-only region created on a projection buffer makes that region read-only to clients of the projection buffer but does not affect the source buffers for that text.

Read-only regions prevent edits only on their owning buffer. A read-only region that does not prohibit edge insertions does not prevent any insertion if the region has (or shrinks to) zero length. A zero-length read-only region that prohibits edge insertions prevents insertions only at its starting position, but allows deletions and modifications that span that position.

remarks.para: At most one object may be active for a particular . It is considered active as long as it has been neither applied nor canceled; calling Dispose() on an unapplied object is equivalent to calling Cancel.
The operations performed using this object do not appear in the until the method has been called.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextBuffer.Changed
member.summary: Occurs when a non-empty is successfully applied.

remarks.para: This is a performance critical event, whose handlers directly affect typing responsiveness. Unless it's required to handle this event synchronously on the UI thread, please consider listening to event instead.
This event is raised after events and before events.

In the case that a second edit is applied by a listener of the Changed event (or the ChangedLowPriority or ChangedHighPriority events), the Changed events for the second edit won't be raised until all listeners have been notified of the first edit (via ChangedLowPriority, Changed, and ChangedHighPriority events). That is, the events for subsequent edits are queued. This ensures listeners receive the Changed events in the order the edits were applied.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextBuffer.ChangedLowPriority
member.summary: Occurs when a non-empty is successfully applied.

remarks.para: This is a performance critical event, whose handlers directly affect typing responsiveness. Unless it's required to handle this event synchronously on the UI thread, please consider listening to event instead.
This event is raised after and events.
Changed events for edits made within a ChangedLowPriority, , or listener are queued. See for more information about event queuing.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextBuffer.ChangedHighPriority
member.summary: Occurs when a non-empty is successfully applied.

remarks.para: This is a performance critical event, whose handlers directly affect typing responsiveness. Unless it's required to handle this event synchronously on the UI thread, please consider listening to event instead.
This event is raised before and events.
Changed events for edits made within a ChangedLowPriority, , or listener are queued. See for more information about event queuing.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextBuffer.Changing
member.summary: Occurs just before a non-empty is applied.

remarks.para: If the edit operation is canceled in this event, another edit operation can be be started immediately in the event handler. For example, this event may be used to provide checkout on edit as an implicit, user-cancelable source control functionality.

member.remarks: Once events have been raised for an edit as well as any resulting edits (i.e. when an edit is made within a Changed listener), the PostChanged event is raised.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextBuffer2
member.summary: A mutable sequence of Unicode characters encoded using UTF-16. Positions within the buffer are treated as a sequence of characters (starting at character zero) or as a sequence of lines (starting at line zero). An empty buffer has a single line containing no characters.
member.remarks: Any will be upcastable to an .

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextBuffer2.ChangedOnBackground
member.summary: Occurs when a non-empty is successfully applied. This is raised on a background thread. Listeners are expected to schedule any expensive work to be done asynchronously outside of this thread.
member.remarks:
Listeners of this event are not expected to modify the buffer. For performance reasons handlers that modify the buffer should listen to event instead.
This event is raised after event. It's guaranteed that individual listeners receive the events in a synchronized way (never on more than one thread at a time) and in the order the edits were applied.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange
member.summary:
Describes a single contiguous text change operation on the Text Buffer.
All text changes are considered to be the replacement of oldText with newText.
Insertion is a text change in which oldText is an empty string and newText a non-empty string.
Deletion is a text change in which oldText is a non-empty string and newText is an empty string.
Modification is a text change in which both oldText and newText are non-empty strings.
member.remarks: objects are immutable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.OldSpan
member.summary: The span of the text change in the snapshot immediately before the change.
member.remarks: This span is empty for a pure insertion. Its start position may differ from NewSpan.Start only when there is more than one included in moving from one snapshot to the next.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.NewSpan
member.summary: The span of the in the snapshot immediately after the change.
member.remarks: This span is empty for a pure deletion. Its start position may differ from OldSpan.Start only when there is more than one included in moving from one snapshot to the next.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.OldPosition
member.summary: The position of the text change in the snapshot immediately before the change. The position can differ from NewPosition only when there is more than one included in moving from one snapshot to the next.
member.remarks: This is the equivalent of OldSpan.Start.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.NewPosition
member.summary: The position of the text change in the snapshot immediately after the change. The position can differ from OldPosition only when there is more than one included in moving from one snapshot to the next.
member.remarks: This is the equivalent of NewSpan.Start.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.Delta
member.summary: The effect On the length of the buffer resulting from this change.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.OldEnd
member.summary: The end position of the in the snapshot immediately before the change.
member.remarks: Equivalent to OldSpan.End.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.NewEnd
member.summary: The end position of the in the snapshot immediately after the text change.
member.remarks: Equivalent to NewSpan.End.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.OldText
member.summary: The text that was replaced.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.NewText
member.summary: The text that replaced the old text.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.OldLength
member.summary: The length of .
member.remarks: This is the equivalent of OldSpan.Length.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange.NewLength
member.summary: The length of .
member.remarks: This is the equivalent of NewSpan.Length.

member.summary: The effect of this change on the number of lines in the snapshot.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange2
member.summary: Extends with the concept of an opaque change.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ITextChange2.IsOpaque
member.summary: Indicates whether the change is opaque. Opaque changes are always replacements in which both the old text and new text are non-empty. The differ from other changes in the manner in which s and s behave. When tracking across an opaque replacement, a point or span endpoint that lies within the deleted text will keep the same offset within the inserted text (normally a point would move either to the beginning or end of the inserted text, depending on its tracking mode).

member.summary: Gets the oldest version number for which all text changes between that version and this version have been canceled out by corresponding undo/redo operations.
member.remarks:
If ReiteratedVersionNumber is not equal to , then for every not originated by an undo operation between ReiteratedVersionNumber and VersionNumber, there is a corresponding originated by an undo operation that cancels it out. So the contents of the two versions are necessarily identical.
Setting this property correctly is the responsibility of the undo system; aside from this property, the text buffer and related classes are unaware of undo and redo.
Note that the created through through an operation that makes no text changes will therefore have the ReiteratedVersionNumber of the previous version.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.PointTrackingMode
member.summary: Represents tracking modes for objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.PointTrackingMode.Positive
member.summary: With this setting, a point tracks toward the end of the document, so that an insertion at the current position pushes the point to the end of the inserted text. If a replacement contains the point, it will end up at the end of the replacement text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.PointTrackingMode.Negative
member.summary: With this setting, a point tracks toward the beginning of the document, so that an insertion at the current position leaves the point unaffected. If a replacement contains the point, it will end up at the beginning of the replacement text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.PositionAffinity.Predecessor
member.summary: The position is coupled to with the preceding character.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.PositionAffinity.Successor
member.summary: The position is coupled to the following character.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpanTrackingMode
member.summary: Represents tracking modes for objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpanTrackingMode.EdgeExclusive
member.summary: The leading edge of the span is positive tracking (insertions push the current position towards the end) and the trailing edge is negative tracking (insertions push the current position towards the start). The span will not expand when text changes occur at the span boundaries. For example, if an EdgeExclusive Span has Start position 3, and a single character is inserted at position 3, the Span will then have Start position 4 and its length will be unchanged.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpanTrackingMode.EdgeInclusive
member.summary: The leading edge of the span is negative tracking (insertions push the current position toward the start) and the trailing edge is positive tracking (insertions push the current position toward the end). The span will expand when text changes occur at the span boundaries. For example, if an EdgeInclusive Span has Start position 3, and a single character is inserted at position 3, the Span will then have Start position 3 and its length will be increased by one.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpanTrackingMode.EdgePositive
member.summary: Both edges of the span are positive tracking (insertions push the current position toward the end).

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpanTrackingMode.EdgeNegative
member.summary: Both edges of the span are negative tracking (insertions push the current position toward the start).

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpanTrackingMode.Custom
member.summary: Custom client-determined tracking behavior.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityMode
member.summary: Represents special tracking behaviors for and objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityMode.Forward
member.summary: When moving back to a previous version (either by explicitly moving to that version or by undo or redo operations), the result may be different from the result that was originally given for that version. This mode is suitable for most purposes, and is the most space-efficient mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityMode.Backward
member.summary: When mapping back to a previous version, the result is the same as the result from mapping forward from the origin version. This mode should be used only for short-lived points and spans.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityMode.UndoRedo
member.summary: When mapping to a version that is the result of undo or redo operations, the result will be the same as the result from mapping forward to the version of which the undo or redo is a reiteration. This mode is more expensive than in both space and time and should be used only if necessary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityModeInternal.Forward
member.summary: When moving back to a previous version (either by explicitly moving to that version or by undo or redo operations), the result may be different from the result that was originally given for that version. This mode is suitable for most purposes, and is the most space-efficient mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityModeInternal.Backward
member.summary: When mapping back to a previous version, the result is the same as the result from mapping forward from the origin version. This mode should be used only for short-lived points and spans.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityModeInternal.UndoRedo
member.summary: When mapping to a version that is the result of undo or redo operations, the result will be the same as the result from mapping forward to the version of which the undo or redo is a reiteration. This mode is more expensive than in both space and time and should be used only if necessary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.TrackingFidelityModeInternal.ForwardOptimizedForReiteratedSnapshots
member.summary: When mapping forward from reiterated version to target version, prefer recreating the span over tracking. This mode is useful when tracking across reversed destructive changes, e.g. deletion followed by an undo. This mode is less efficient than and more efficient than .

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Utilities.TrackingSpanTree`1
member.summary: Holds a well-formed tree of tracking spans and correlated items, for tracking the position and movement of spans over time. Allows for efficient addition, removal, and searching over the tree, with methods for searching for intersection and containment over both and arguments. The search results are returned pre-order (so parents before children, children closest to the start of the buffer first).

remarks.para: Well-formed means the relationship between all spans is either non-overlapping (siblings) or containment (parent-child), so there can be no partially overlapping spans.
The only tracking mode that can be safely used is , as the other tracking modes can result in overlapping spans as the buffer changes.

member.typeparam: The type of object that each span correlates to.
member.comment: This is used by the outlining manager to store collapsed regions and the outlining shims to store all hidden region adapters.

member.summary: Create a tracking span tree for the given buffer.
member.param: The buffer that all the spans in this tree are in.
The tree should not allow tracking spans to point to old versions, at the expense of walking the tree on every text change.
